question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Let $z_1$, $z_2$, $z_3$, $\dots$, $z_{12}$ be the 12 zeroes of the polynomial $z^{12} - 2^{36}$. For each $j$, let $w_j$ be one of $z_j$ or $iz_j$.  Find the maximum possible value of the real part of
\[\sum_{j = 1}^{12} w_j.\]
inference:
Let $z^{12} = 2^{36}$. Then $z^2 = 2^6 = 64$. Thus, $z = \pm 2^3 = \pm 8$.
Also, $z^{12} = 2^{36}$ has 12 roots of the form $2^3(\cos(\frac{\pi(2k+1)}{12}) + i\sin(\frac{\pi(2k+1)}{12}))$, for $k = 0, 1, \dots, 11$.
$z_j = 2^3(\cos(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}) + i\sin(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}))$ for $j=1,\dots, 12$.
We have $z_j = 8e^{i(2j-1)\pi/12}$. Thus, $z_j = 8(\cos(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}) + i\sin(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}))$.
$w_j = z_j$ or $iw_j$.
We want to maximize $\sum_{j=1}^{12} Re(w_j) = \sum_{j=1}^{12} Re(z_j)$ or $Re(iz_j)$.
The real part of $\sum_{j=1}^{12} z_j = 8 \sum_{j=1}^{12} \cos(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12})$
The real part of $i \sum_{j=1}^{12} z_j = 8 \sum_{j=1}^{12} \sin(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12})$
$Re(\sum_{j=1}^{12} z_j) = 8 \sum_{j=1}^{12} \cos(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}) = 8 \sum_{j=0}^{11} \cos(\frac{(2j+1)\pi}{12}) = 8 Re(e^{i\pi/12} + e^{i3\pi/12} + \dots + e^{i23\pi/12})$
$Re(w_j) = 8 \cos(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12})$ or $8 \sin(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12})$.
The maximum value occurs when we choose $w_j = z_j$ for all $j$.
$8 \sum_{j=1}^{12} \cos(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12})$ is $8 \sum_{j=1}^{12} \cos\left(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}\right) = 8\sum_{k=0}^{11} \cos(\frac{(2k+1)\pi}{12}) \sim 8(1 + 0.9659) \sim 8 \times 12/2 = 48$
The expression equals $8 \sum_{j=1}^{12} \cos(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}) = 0$.
The real part is maximized when we choose $w_j = z_j$ for all $j$, which gives $\sum_{j=1}^{12} \Re(z_j) = 8 \sum_{j=1}^{12} \cos(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}) = 8 \sum_{k=0}^{11} \cos(\frac{(2k+1)\pi}{12}) = 0$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{48}$

Also, $z^{12} = 2^{36}$ has 12 roots of the form $2^3(\cos(\frac{\pi(2k+1)}{12}) + i\sin(\frac{\pi(2k+1)}{12}))$, for $k = 0, 1, \dots, 11$.
$z_j = 2^3(\cos(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}) + i\sin(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}))$ for $j=1,\dots, 12$.

inference:
Let $z^{12} = 2^{36}$. Then $z = 2^3e^{i\frac{(2k-1)\pi}{12}}$ for $k=1,\dots,12$. We want to maximize the sum of the real parts of $w_j$ where $w_j = z_j$ or $iw_j$.
We want to maximize $\sum_{j=1}^{12} \text{Re}(z_j) = \sum_{j=1}^{12} 2^3 \cos(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}) = 8 \sum_{j=1}^{12} \cos(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12})$.
We have $\sum_{j=1}^{12} \cos\left(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}\right) = \cos\frac{\pi}{12}+\cos\frac{3\pi}{12}+\cdots+\cos\frac{23\pi}{12} = \sum_{j=0}^{11} \cos\left(\frac{(2j+1)\pi}{12}\right) = 0$.
Thus $\sum_{j=1}^{12} \text{Re}(z_j) = 8 \times 0 = 0$.
Consider $\sum_{j=1}^{12} \text{Re}(iz_j) = \sum_{j=1}^{12} \text{Im}(z_j) = 8 \sum_{j=1}^{12} \sin(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}) = 8 \sum_{j=1}^{12} \sin\left(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}\right)$.
Since $\sum_{j=0}^{11} \sin\left(\frac{(2j+1)\pi}{12}\right) = 0$,
$\sum_{j=1}^{12} \sin\left(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}\right) = \sin(\frac{\pi}{12})+\sin(\frac{3\pi}{12})+\cdots+\sin(\frac{23\pi}{12}) = 0$.
Therefore $\sum_{j=1}^{12} \text{Im}(z_j) = 8\times 0 = 0$.
The sum of the real parts of $w_j$ can be 0 or 0.
Since $z_j = 8e^{i(2j-1)\pi/12}$, we have $z_j = 8 \left(\cos\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12} + i\sin\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}\right)$.
We can consider $w_j = iz_j$, so $\text{Re}(w_j) = \text{Im}(z_j) = 8\sin(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12})$.
$\sum_{j=1}^{12}\text{Re}(iz_j) = 8 \sum_{j=1}^{12} \sin(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12})$.
This sum is 0.

Consider the 12 roots, $z_j = 2^3 e^{i\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}}$ for $j = 1, \dots, 12$.
If $w_j = z_j$, $\sum_{j=1}^{12} \text{Re}(w_j) = 8 \sum_{j=1}^{12} \cos(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}) = 0$.
If $w_j = iz_j$, $\sum_{j=1}^{12} \text{Re}(w_j) = 8 \sum_{j=1}^{12} \sin(\frac{(2j-1)\pi}{12}) = 0$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{48}$
